content: crosswinds cowl by lauren k designs the cables on this cowl crossing each other and interlocking form a warm weaving fabric that were inspired by the windy area i live near a small regional airport where small planes take joyrides from time to time and inspire wonder in the little children in my neighborhood as soon as i learned this cable pattern i knew i had to use it for something so here s hoping this cowl will protect you from the cold and help you feel a little more stylish every time you reach for it crosswinds cowl - lauren k designs - pg 1 supplies 200g aran weight yarn i used 1 ball lion brand schitt s creek in color bebe blue 5mm needles cable needle darning needle for seaming and weaving in ends gauge is not particularly important in this cowl but for reference my finished product using 5mm needles came out to be 6 inches wide and 10 inches long when seamed into a loop abbreviations & sitches k - knit p - purl st/sts - stitch/stitches c4b - cable 4 back - slip next 2 stitches onto cable needle hold at back of work knit next 2 stitches from left hand needle then knit the 2 stitches from the cable needle t4b - twist 4 back - slip next 2 stitches onto cable needle and hold at back of work then knit next 2 stitches from left hand needle and purl 2 stitches from the cable needle t4f - twist 4 front - slip next 2 stitches onto cable needle and hold at front of work then purl next 2 stitches from left hand needle and knit 2 stitches from cable needle pattern cast on 42 stitches using long-tail cast on method knit the pattern repeat 15 total times row 1 rs p3 c4b *p4 c4b* repeat from * to last 3 sts p3 row 2 ws k3 p4 *k4 p4* repeat from * to last 3 sts k3 row 3 p1 *t4b t4f* repeat from * to last st p1 row 4 k1 p2 k4 *p4 k4* repeat from * to last 3 sts p2 k1 row 5 p1 k2 p4 *c4b p4* repeat from * to last 3 sts k2 p1 row 6 repeat row 4 row 7 p1 *t4f t4b* repeat from * to last st p1 row 8 repeat row 2 note if you would like to make a longer cowl you can continue this repeat until it reaches your desired length another option is to make it into a scarf instead of a closed loop cowl - the choice is yours regardless of your chosen cowl length cast off on row 7 using your preferred cast off method leaving enough of a tail to seam the cowl together with right sides facing each other seam the two ends together to form the cowl then wash according to the yarn label and gently block so the sides lay flat crosswinds cowl
